gov.ca.dmv.ease.core.dl.validator.impl
Class AbstractSpRule

java.lang.Object
  gov.ca.dmv.ease.validator.impl.AbstractValidateRule
      gov.ca.dmv.ease.core.dl.validator.impl.AbstractSpRule
All Implemented Interfaces:
gov.ca.dmv.ease.validator.IValidationRule
Direct Known Subclasses:
Sp0575Rule, Sp0576Rule, SpD008Rule, SpD013Rule, SpD053Rule, SpD085Rule, SpD095Rule, SpD505Rule, SpD506Rule, SpD519Rule, SpD527Rule, SpD534Rule, SpD560Rule, SpD569Rule, SpD584Rule, SpD608Rule, SpD612Rule, SpD623Rule, SpD630Rule, SpD661Rule, SpD670Rule, SpD676Rule, SpD677Rule, SpD680Rule, SpD696Rule, SpD718Rule, SpD720Rule, SpD742Rule, SpF005Rule, SpF511Rule, SpQ569Rule
public abstract class AbstractSpRule
extends gov.ca.dmv.ease.validator.impl.AbstractValidateRule

Description: Abstract class for SP validation rules. Make sure to return null in the case that any of the sought after objects or their parents are not found and let the inheriting rule make the business decision about what to do about the missing object. File: AbstractSpRule.java Module: gov.ca.dmv.ease.core.dl.validator.impl Created: Jul 29, 2010

Version:
$Revision: 1.16 $ Last Changed: $Date: 2010/08/16 18:35:13 $ Last Changed By: $Author: mwcyl $
Author:
MWJXA11

Constructor Detail

AbstractSpRule

public AbstractSpRule()
automatically adds an ErrorCollector to the validation rule. Then you never have to write the boiler plate errorCollector registering code. Just register errors with getErrorCollector().register(.....

getDaysToSalesLicenseExpiration

protected int getDaysToSalesLicenseExpiration(gov.ca.dmv.ease.app.context.impl.ProcessContext context)
return the number of days difference between the current working date and the license expiration date. If the number is > 0 the license has not expired. If it is negative it has.

Parameters:
context - the context
Returns:
the days to sales license expiration

getDateDifferenceInDays

protected int getDateDifferenceInDays(java.util.Date firstDate,
                                      java.util.Date secondDate)
                               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Get the difference in days between two dates. If the difference is less than .5 days then return 0. If the firstDate is later than the second date then the return value will be positive. Otherwise the difference is negative or zero.

Parameters:
firstDate - the first date
secondDate - the second date
Returns:
the date difference in days
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - the illegal argument exception
